source_text.text:
﻿The tyrant Zahhak grows serpents from his shoulders and feeds them the brains of youths to keep them quiet. Kaveh the blacksmith refuses to surrender his last son, denouncing the court’s injustice. He rips off his leather apron, raises it on a spear as a banner, and rallies the people.
Prophecies say a child named Feraydun will end Zahhak’s reign. Kaveh joins the child’s hidden supporters and helps arm the rebels. The movement spreads through towns hungry for justice.
Zahhak marches to crush the uprising, but the rebels seize strongholds and free captives. Feraydun strikes Zahhak down and binds him in Mount Damavand rather than killing him outright.
With the tyrant chained, Kaveh’s apron becomes a royal standard. Justice and popular solidarity replace terror; the story frames rebellion as righteous duty.

paragraph_summaries: Zahhak’s shoulders sprout serpents that demand human brains; he rules by terror, sacrificing youths.
Blacksmith Kaveh refuses to give his last son, denounces Zahhak, and raises his leather apron as a rebellion banner.
Kaveh joins Feraydun; the uprising spreads, seizing strongholds and freeing captives.
Feraydun strikes Zahhak down and binds him in Mount Damavand; the people are freed and the banner becomes a standard of justice.

propp_functions.evidence: Zahhak’s demand for youths’ brains as tribute; implicit taboo against refusal.
Kaveh refuses tribute, breaking the tyrant’s command.
Kaveh raises the leather apron as a revolt banner.
People freed from sacrifice; justice restored.
